comments.commentBody:
John Keglovitz, Austin, Texas

Andrea E
Is your memory so short that you can't remember that the economy was in a total meltdown when President Obama took office?

***
No which is why I don't fault Obama for relying completely on Paulson, a Wall Street type democrats love to hate, for getting us out of a potential catastrophe. Obama faced the precipice and knew enough not to interfere with those who had the ability to prevent a collapse.

I only fault him for not recognizing the taxpayer's cost and how it would appear to Americans who weren't going to be bailed out. Taxpayers needed an "investment banker" at that deal table. Obama could never have foreseen that there would be resentment because he didn't understand the importance of spending to taxpaying Americans. And still doesn't.

SD, Rochester:

You can thank republicans for these trends. Obama's trending was in a different direction until his party received its "shellacking". In fact, it was the cause.

Len:

Unions need to figure out how to fit into a global economy. Their old role has become extinct. IMO, they should partner with businesses, which have already figured out how to compete globally. The tax code should reward this partnership.

Andrea, always looking for solutions, surrounded by naysayers who just want to complain and fix blame on anyone not themselves. It may be a pyrrhic fight, particularly in this forum; but it's an honorable one.
Well, Andrea, perhaps we should require union representation on companies' board of directors as they do in Germany which seems to have little problem competing.

OK, Mr. Gillespie, what are Republicans for?

Shutting down the government, destroying the chance for ordinary Americans with pre-existing conditions to get health care, playing Russian roulette with the country's future by refusing to raise the debt limit, making it harder for women to have access to birth control, demonizing immigrants brought to the U. S. as children, cutting food stamps at a time of high unemployment, enriching the very rich and subsidizing wealthy corporations.

But they're against bringing the "open the government" bill to the House floor so that it can be voted on, which is democracy.

It is said that engineers are overpaid when they are starting their careers (inexperienced), and are, basically in training, and underpaid in the twilight of their careers. People can move into many engineering jobs through experience only. I have known people doing the same job I did who only graduated from high school. Any docs who can say that? they have a better union. An engineer can kill or injure more people at one time thru mistakes than any doctor e.g. airplanes, bridges, etc.

Engineers in Europe, as I recall, receive more respect than US. Are docs practicing in Europe griping?

Your sharing of this trip through hell and back has been as generous as, I hope, it has been healing for your readers and yourself.  I am amazed and heartened by your determination to go public with your story, and in doing so, to open new doors that would not have been available to you otherwise.  Like many of your other readers who have struggled with cancer and its horrifying treatments, I thank you and hope to hear more from you in years ahead.

While I agree with you, I think it's their skill at psychology and messaging that has gotten them as far as they've come. I believe it's why people with much to lose under today's Republican Party continue to vote for them and eagerly cut their own throats.
Sort of like snake oil salesmen.
When you come from a place where the voters are ignorant, sales and marketing are very effective. These guys work very hard to keep their voters ignorant.

These guys still think it is about the packaging of the message and not the message itself.  It's all sales and marketing and no real production.  Kind of an ironic reflection of their aversion to workers who actually do work, as opposed to those who rig the pay scales in favor the c-class that just sell that work.

Terrific essay.

While I have no opinion about your mother's dating skills, I think she did an excellent job of raising her son!
They have proposed something, abandoning the ACA. They are cruel and mean. PB
You don't get any ideas from a screaming two-year-old, why should we expect anything different from the Tea Publicans whose "ideas" makes that same two-year-old look like a Rhodes Scholar?

Ironically what the Republicans proposed a few years ago is Obama/RomneyCare! This whole idea of subsidized private health insurance instead of simply extending single-payer Medicare for all was hatched some years ago by the Heritage Foundation. It was then put in place when Romney was Governor of Massachusetts.
Before becoming President Obama said single-payer made the most sense and he supported it. But then Obama let Sen Max Baucus, one of the top recipients of insurance contributions, simply deny single-payer advocates any role in coming up with Obamacare with its $70 Billion private insurer subsidy and forced individual contributions ala ROMNEY Care!
But now the Republicans are against their own "innovative" rightwing solution!

Obviously the Republicans are either against any real progress for the 99% vs 1% or just put up sham "reforms" ie privatization of public schools by plutocrat Hedge Funds which either delay real change or actually make things worse.

The most interesting thing in this entire crying session was the total lack of Republican ideas and solutions and the total focus on just getting back into power.

President Obama talks about solutions. The Republicans talk about political strategy.

Take health care, for example. We have THE MOST EXPENSIVE health care in the world by far and the quality, by any broad measure, is only average at best. President Obama has put forth a solution. What have the Republicans proposed?
Oops, meant to address my comment to Andrea E, not NVFisherman! However, NVFisherman, I'd point out that California's financial difficulties began with the conservative, anti-tax Proposition 13.

NA, New York:

New Yorkers no longer like their wealthy benefactors and will elect a liberal to make their distaste for wealth known. A primary criticism of Bloomberg has been his wealth.

As for homelessness, the problem is not more people entering the shelter system. The problem is that people are staying in temporary housing longer because of the lack of a vehicle to move them out.

Bloomberg had a chance to see the shelter system up close and believes the entry criteria are too lax. At one point, he predicted an uprising over the cost of homeless shelters.

New Yorkers need someone rational like Bloomberg to counter the influence of organizations like the Coalition for the Homeless, which are in the business of homelessness.

@Andrea E: "Bloomberg had a chance to see the shelter system up close and believes the entry criteria are too lax."

I'm sure he does believe that. I also know that there are more homeless out on the street, including the disturbed man who attacked multiple people with scissors in Riverside Park earlier this week--and that this was preceded in recent months by others in areas that had been considered safe. This is reflective of what you regard as "sound Republican principles"--i.e., identifying a social problem and then throwing up your hands when your "solution" only makes things worse.

As for resentment of his wealth, it would be nice to see some support for such a general statement. For once.

This is interesting.  I still live in a State and state of mind in which it is hard to understand voting for a Republican.  This seems to be a grinding fight to the death for this horrible ideology.  And nothing but death for it is required.

Did you have any other puzzle connections in mind besides FLUBBER, John?

I mean, I know that in My TWEE Sons he played a MAN; and that in Caine Mutiny his character BRIEFed another character, but I'm always curious to know what connections you have in mind when you actually choose the avatar.

One is certainly sufficient!

bmessina/SD

The people referenced in this article reside in some of the higher income eligible states. Who are the low income stated you mentioned? What portion of the 312 million population reside there? Whatever the income limitations, today Medicaid in fact covers 55 million people!

The health care cost problem will never be solved by pouring more money into the current system. It will be solved when we make individuals responsible for their own conduct. If you smoke, do drugs, drink excessively, have unprotected sex, eat too much and are obese, you should be responsible for the associated health consequences.

Imagine what auto insurance would cost if you drove too fast, had numerous accidents, kept your car in poor repair, drove in high traffic environments and then were guaranteed full coverage insurance paid for by someone else. That's health care today. Then you wonder why the costs are so high.

Of course there are people in need through no fault of their own who should be helped if they can not afford it. They are in the minority of those eligible.

This is not the "what you can do for your country" crowd! But there were plenty of early warning signs.

Many GOP Congress members by all reports, drink on duty and way too much, see freedom as a low cost provision. They think its defense requires personal guns; its central issue, bloat--giveaways to people of color, including cars, cell phones, and food stamps; and the infringement of personal liberties by collecting taxes and addresses. They repeat stories of Obama building concentration camps, assembling hidden international armies to round up civilians based on Executive Order 11000 and UN Agenda 21. Don't forget last month's impeachment chatter.

MSNBC's Chris Matthews acknowledges Congress members sharing slurs, insults and disrespectful comments he calls "rejectionist." Other incidents were confirmed by Rep. Peter King!

The GOP, its federation of supporters, from avowed racists to moderates, are determined to put a black mark on Obama's presidency. And destroy the country's safety net

The media speaks of a "split." The story is the holdouts who think, in the face of growing acceptance of the ACA, the public tide will soon turn against the President. This is magical thinking! If you listened to the Heads of State speeches at the UN, it's out of step with the world!

Xs and Q and Zs, oh my!

Almost a pangram - just a J short; too bad we can't replace the odious OXIDATE with some J word ...

As for MONSTER, please remember that in the movies, as well as in the popular imagination, Frankenstein IS the monster (cf "Bride of ...").

FWIW, a big thanks to the emus for finally posting my original comment from yesterday, with the actual text for those two "modern" fills (which I won't push my luck and repeat here ...).
Let's also not forget that October 6th marks the 40th anniversary of the Yom Kippur War.
Joshua: you plainly missed my point.  In any case, if the Israelis would stop colonizing the West Bank in the name of "security" your country would be far more secure than it is now.

Joshua, Israel
The only way to stop all this warmongering is essentially elect a government that respect human beings and do not treat them as animals in a cage, even if they are the ones from occupied Gaza and the West Bank. As long as your country is the occupying force, the resistance will be there and people may die.
Give peace a chance. One has to work at it though.

Prime Minister Netanyahu has been amazingly restrained about taking significant action against Israel's enemies. George W. Bush invaded Iraq on lies about WMD and because Saddam Hussein allegedly threatened Bush's father. On the same day that Americans were celebrating the 200th year of their independence, Bibi's older brother, Jonathan, was killed by terrorists while saving Jewish hostages in Entebbe. That's how personal the issue is for him. It's not Israel that will start WWIII.

I got an error message after successfully opening an account for my spouse (to see if he can improve on his very limited employer coverage), so I called the phone number and was speaking to an articulate and well-informed young woman in less than a minute. She said the "error" was just the system being overwhelmed and to wait a few days and try again.

Websites crashing from unusually heavy traffic is not uncommon in computerworld, so I don't see what the fuss is all about? There is plenty of time to enroll and there will be other ways to apply. The website was functioning as far as giving information as to alternative ways of applying when I was there--at five in the morning on Oct. 1. I contacted one of the groups and was told they were waiting for their certification to come through and apologized profusely. I said I could wait--lord knows we've waited for sixty years or so, what's another few days or weeks?

If Republican state governors had not refused the Medicaid expansion and built the state-level exchanges the Act envisioned, the demand would have been spread across all the states.  As it stands, the Federal government has to handle all the traffic for the states that refused to take part.

It's exciting that the ACA is beginning to be implemented. The strong initial response level shows how much the program is needed, and the program will produce substantial economic activity in the health care sector.

The initial implementation glitches definitely need to be addressed. I checked out my state's site on the night of October 1. While the site was operational, I was told that my identity could not be confirmed on the basis of my name, address and SSN, and was advised to contact a counselor. I'd heartily support additional hiring of IT staff to get all needed systems up to par so that the new law is implemented smoothly and seamlessly.

Many years ago, when I was just starting out, I was fortunate to receive an assignment where I would cover a ski race with Bill. The snow turned to rain and it was a pretty miserable shoot, but for a few days I followed Bill around and did whatever he asked, including wearing a motorcycle helmet with a motorized Nikon mounted on the top as I skied down a hill. (No memorable photos there.) I still remember the evenings where I hung on every word and bit of wisdom that he shared with a young photojournalist.

Fast forward to a few years ago when Bill and Adrienne visited the school where I teach and I saw that he still had the energy and ability to inspire young photographers. During those few days we were the last people to leave the building every night because Bill was surrounded by groups of journalism students who showed him work and listened carefully to everything he had to offer.

Over the years our paths would cross from time to time and I was struck by the impression that he was always giving to others. He’ll be missed not only by those who knew him but also by those young photographers who never had the chance to meet him.
Peter Turnley's work is wholly derivative and uninspiring. If you're going to set yourself up for comparison to great photographers of the past, your work better be pretty damn good.  His is not.
Absolutely beautiful images of Paris. I never feel more alive and romantic, than when I'm there. It has my heart and soul.
For those who received a Jesuit education, we knew Francis immediatelyand we were immediately hopeful. I know I'm not disappointed.
We are hopeful, it begins with words, lets see(pray?) action.

I was raised Catholic and though no longer practicing, I like Pope Francis' words, which are sincere and bring hope. Loving and caring exude from his words and actions.

He speaks of inclusiveness and openness in the church, even of past corruption. The Pope's secretary speaks of priestly celibacy as 'a tradition', not dogma, and indicates that even this once sacrosanct ideal is open for discussion.

I wonder how a talk between this new Pope and the Dalai Lama would go, I think they may have many ideas in common.

I also am a bit of a nit picker so was disappointed with MONSTER but like the old comic book letter writers who questioned the bad science in super hero ones, especially Flash, we were encouraged to give our own possible solutions. So I thought some solvers would say poor misunderstood Dr. Frankenstein was indeed a monster. But I did have fun solving today's puzzle.

Have you looked at these insurance exchanges yet? The prices are what they always were, even for those that cover only 60% of expenses --- $480/month is the lowest. I don't see how a plumber making $60,000 a year can afford that. I'm an independent engineer I can't afford it. I will pay the penalty.

Everyone needs healthcare, at every stage of life. When I was in my 20's and 30's I consumed a lot of it. Sports injuries. I was an employed engineer so I had health insurance.

An engineer in Silicon Valley, on average, generates $1M a year for their company. It's pretty difficult to see someone at 55 laid off after 30 years of productive work unable to get coverage because of pre-existing conditions, or unable to buy insurance on the private market because it's over $20,000 an year.

The young don't think they need it, and the old can't afford it, but the reality is that these two groups generate the demand for health care. The ACA is not perfect, but it's a step in addressing medical reality.
You beat me to it today, Howie!  No worries, of course, I'll find another muscial link.

44D reminds me of my H.S. graduation year of 1955, when "Mr. Earl" and his song were a MONSTER hit!

http://youtu.be/p9uZvrsAoyE

Howie TBOQ

Quaker John:

The damage done to our country will ultimately depend largely on how we (as in "We the people") respond to this bit of history. Will we learn anything from it? And do something? Anything that will make our democracy and society stronger going forward? Or will we just be glad it's over, put it out of our minds, and race along to the next social/political mistakes?

The choices we -- the electorate, the citizens -- make AFTER the sun sets on the current band of Republican radicals will decide how much damage they did to America in the long term. If we make the right choices, if we are sincere and demanding of effective reform, we might find -- amazingly -- something like a bargain in all of this. Historically speaking, of course.

Well, it's a nice thought anyway.

Republicans have been on a mission for years. Never forget the agreement made the night of President Obama's State of the Union Address by Republican leadership to obstruct him and his Presidency in all things....or, the hateful yell "You lie!" They haven't wavered from this self-serving, irresponsible tactic and deserve our disgust. The fact that their campaign has cost America and its people dearly is collateral damage to Republicans. The real shocker was Obama winning a second term - decisively. For a day or two, leadership was humble..."the people have spoken". But it was short-lived. Throughout, President Obama has remained Presidential and each day does his job - for the American people. He has made mistakes but they have not been mistakes of hate, like his detractors who continue to criticize him, demonize him, and totally obstruct his efforts to help America's people survive this recession.

Who do Republicans really think they are hurting?

I used to see value in a strong two-party system; however, for it to work in a Democracy, politicians must be responsible. Once again, Mr. Egan does a masterful job of calling out the extremism within the Republican Party and the lack of statesmanship from the majority of that party who knows better.

The Tea Party is a small group of narcissistic, extreme right persons who are not representative of the majority of America. The other Republicans don't get a pass. This is not about them; it is about America!

A brilliant compilation Mr. Egan of all that is so very wrong and tragic about the takeover of the Republican Party by the Tea Partiers.  And while the future will survive them and leave them behind very soon, sadly it will not do so soon enough to prevent them from doing very real damage to our country and to so many individuals most directly dependent on the programs our civil servants provide.
The Emancipation Proclamation was issued six months before Gettysburg.  It followed Antietam, not Gettysburg.

If this analogy holds, I hope that President Obama and the Democrats will learn from the mistakes the Union Army made after Gettysburg, and will crush the opposition quickly as it tries to escape from its self-inflicted error.

I think the Battle at Gettysburg might be an analogy for today's GOP attack on Washington and he ACA.

"With his army in high spirits, Lee.... hoped to influence Northern politicians to give up their prosecution of the war by penetrating as far as Harrisburg, Pennsylvania, or even Philadelphia."

"...a dramatic infantry assault by Confederates against... the Union line... was repulsed by Union fire, at great losses to the Confederate....

"Lee led his army on a torturous retreat... the battle... is often described as the war's turning point"

Source: Wikipedia Battle of Gettysburg

Casualties from over 50 million uninsured easily exceed those of Gettysburg, every year.

Like Robert E Lee, the GOP has massively miscalculated their assault on Washington.

Lincoln made Gettysburg, a turning point for the war, an opportunity to redefine the cause to emancipation.

We are on the cusp of a similar moment in American history.

KS, I'm presently somewhat slightly stewed, what's your excuse!

WHH

KS,

Don't you just hate it when a waiter hands you a menu that was printed upside down?

You reminded me of the two carpenters who were building a house. One saw the other throwing away some of the nails. When asked why, he said those nails wouldn't work, since they were facing the wrong direction. His buddy said, "You idiot! We could have used those on the other side of the house."

I know this great puzzle has an extra level of symmetry, i.e. when you rotate it even just 90 degrees it looks the same. However, I tried that when I finished, and all the letters I filled in looked sideways.
My sentiments, exactly. Thanks for stating it so succinctly!

Defund Obamacare, that was the objective. That and continuation of sequester level spending. In exchange the insurrectionist neo-confederates, who have no interest in governing only the destruction of a government which serves anyone other than the .01% and requires no legislation, only a series of manufactured crises when it demands more and more freedom and respect.

Systematically they will demand freedom from voting, freedom from a living wage and safe working conditions and wage and hours laws, freedom from the habit forming programs like Social Security, Medicare, Medicaid, unemployment insurance, freedom from Dodd-Frank and any limitation on the power of banks and corporations from doing exactly what they want.

They will demand freedom from justice, fairness, equality before the law, democracy and good government. They also shall demand freedom to pillage the commons, our natural resources and to despoil our environment for the profit of the .01%.

They plan to achieve this by blackmail, extortion and taking the nation hostage. They want respect, love and deference. They revel in the injury they are inflicting but they to not wish to be called traitors, fascists, terrorists, corrupt and nut cases. They do not want their feelings hurt.

America needs to disrespect the Republican party as synonymous with traitors, fascists, terrorists, corrupted by bags of cash and ignorant nut cases. If the shoe fits etc., let them know what we think of them loud and often.

I'd be interested to see stats which support the allegation that a difference in the # of wealthy (that could also use definition) in a state makes an appreciable difference in revenue. In addition to that, consider the tax cuts and loopholes which increasingly reduce tax costs the greater the income.

That "the poor have a higher birth rate" rings more of propaganda than factual evidence. Link it (and not from a site which screams birther, Kenyan, Moslem, socialist, communist, gay nonsense about our President). White, middle class Catholic and Mormon families are more likely to be larger than those in poverty (I'd guess).

I agree with Mmac and will add the following from Wikipedia:

"A 2004 OECD report said: 'With the exception of Mexico, Turkey, and the United States, all OECD countries had achieved universal or near-universal (at least 98.4% insured) coverage of their populations by 1990.'" That is tragic.
